post_text:
Students at Frankfort 157-C participated in ‚ÄúOne Book, One Summer‚Äù reading challenge throughout the month of July. ‚ÄúOne Book, One Summer‚Äù was designed to ensure students stayed engaged before returning to school later this month.

A copy of the selection for this optional reading challenge was included in each child‚Äôs end of year supply box. The selection for Chelsea was The Miraculous Journey of Edward Tulane. Charlotte‚Äôs Web was the selected novel for Grand Prairie and The Maze Runner was chosen for students at Hickory Creek.
Teachers created interactive activities to go along with each book, encouraging students to draw the characters, participate in STEM activities and star gazing scavenger hunts, and crack cryptography codes. Frankfort 157-C looks forward to discussing the book with all our students when they return in the fall.

post_text:
On Tuesday, August 18, Grand Prairie will be hosting a Kindergarten Meet & Greet from 3:30 ‚Äì 5:00 PM. Your child‚Äôs teacher will send out a sign-up genius form in the next few weeks to sign up for a 30 minute time slot.

Due to ISBE and IDPH guidelines regarding social distancing practices, students will be limited to bringing ONE parent or guardian with them and siblings are not allowed. All visitors must wear a mask to enter the building and for the duration of their visit. We apologize in advance for any inconvenience this may cause, but student and staff safety is our top priority. We greatly appreciate your support and assistance with adhering to ISBE and IDPH guidelines.

Tricia Dotson brings experience, skill and a true love for education to her new role as principal of Hickory Creek Middle School at the start of the 2020-2021 school year.

Dotson was selected as the school‚Äôs principal at the June meeting of the Frankfort District 157-C Board of Education. She will succeed Jason Crockett, who is stepping down to become the school‚Äôs assistant principal.

To read more, click here.

https://patch.com/illinois/frankfort/tricia-dotson-named-principal-hickory-creek-middle-school

post_text:
Happy Kindness Week! We are so excited to spread kindness, joy and positivity all week! The businesses listed on the flyer below are handing out handmade stickers, created by D157-C students, all week in celebration of kindness.
You'll also see, pictured below, that students at Grand Prairie submitted handmade valentines for veterans to brighten their day on Friday! #FrankfortKindness

Frankfort School District 157-C students are encouraging the spread of positivity and kindness throughout the community through the Frankfort Kindness Project.

During the week of February 9-15, Frankfort residents and visitors can stop by one of 30 Frankfort businesses to receive a handmade sticker with a positive message. Students at all three District 157-C schools created the stickers, which share kind and friendly messages for recipients.

Click below to read more! #FrankfortKindness

post_text:
The Hickory Creek Middle School Tigers varsity softball team enjoyed the shared fun and camaraderie of their sport during a friendly face-off with the Tinley Park Bobcat Challengers on Thursday, September 12 at Bettenhausen Park in Tinley Park.

"The experience was one I will never forget," said Mitch Stein, softball coach at Hickory Creek. "It was a perfect night. Coach Erin Nemeth and I were just in awe of how well our girls interacted with these amazing athletes. I was just taking everything in and had a smile on my face the whole time. It was the best game we played all year."
shared_text:
PATCH.COM
Hickory Creek softball takes on Tinley Park Bobcat Challengers
text:
The Hickory Creek Middle School Tigers varsity softball team enjoyed the shared fun and camaraderie of their sport during a friendly face-off with the Tinley Park Bobcat Challengers on Thursday, September 12 at Bettenhausen Park in Tinley Park.

"The experience was one I will never forget," said Mitch Stein, softball coach at Hickory Creek. "It was a perfect night. Coach Erin Nemeth and I were just in awe of how well our girls interacted with these amazing athletes. I was just taking everything in and had a smile on my face the whole time. It was the best game we played all year."

post_text: Throughout the district, students and staff reflected on 9/11 today. Students in Mrs. Holthouse's third-grade class reflected on Patriot Day by reading "Fireboat: The Heroic Adventures of the John J. Harvey" and completing an assignment describing a hero. Students in Mrs. Michalski's fifth-grade advanced ELA class read the lyrics to "Where Were You When the World Stopped Turning" and reviewed the picture book "14 Cows for America" to reflect on hope, love, and faith in connection to 9/11.
text: Throughout the district, students and staff reflected on 9/11 today. Students in Mrs. Holthouse's third-grade class reflected on Patriot Day by reading "Fireboat: The Heroic Adventures of the John J. Harvey" and completing an assignment describing a hero. Students in Mrs. Michalski's fifth-grade advanced ELA class read the lyrics to "Where Were You When the World Stopped Turning" and reviewed the picture book "14 Cows for America" to reflect on hope, love, and faith in connection to 9/11.

post_text:
The Frankfort community is invited to watch an exciting game of wheelchair basketball while supporting the Lincolnway Special Recreation Association at 6 p.m. tonight at Hickory Creek Middle School.
Students and staff members from Hickory Creek will face the LWSRA Hawks in a friendly, fun game.
It is free to attend the game, but donations will be accepted at the door to support the LWSRA in its mission to provide recreation and leisure services for individuals with physical or intellectual disabilities while promoting greater disability awareness in the community.
For more information about the game, call Hickory Creek Middle School at (815) 469-4474.

"I admire a child's honesty and creativity, which reminds me of my childhood. Helping children is the most rewarding part of being the new DRO for District 157-C."

post_text:
Due to the extended forecast for extreme temperatures, all schools and the district office will now be closed on Wednesday, January 30 and Thursday, January 31, 2019. There will be no after-school activities beginning this afternoon. School and extra-curricular activities (both before and after school) will resume to the normal schedule on Friday, February 1, 2019.

The Education Foundation Hot Lunch scheduled at Hickory Creek for Wednesday and at Grand Prairie for Thursday will be rescheduled for this Friday, February 1 at both schools for students who have pre-ordered this hot lunch.

At this point, all three emergency days will be made up at the end of the school year.
text:

The Education Foundation Hot Lunch scheduled at Hickory Creek for Wednesday and at Grand Prairie for Thursday will be rescheduled for this Friday, February 1 at both schools for students who have pre-ordered this hot lunch.

At this point, all three emergency days will be made up at the end of the school year.

post_text:
From everyone at our district, thank you, veterans! Please join us tomorrow for presentations in honor of veterans at each of our schools.
At 8 a.m, Hickory Creek students will present tributes to veterans and raise funds for Chicago Honor Flight. American Education Week visitation will follow from 9:15 a.m.-10:15 a.m.
At 9 a.m., Grand Prairie second-graders will perform a musical appreciation concert for veterans. American Education Week visitation will be from 10:15 a.m.-11:15 a.m.
At 10:30 a.m. Chelsea students will provide a tribute to veterans. American Education Week visitation will follow from 11:15 a.m.-12:15 p.m.
If you plan on attending a presentation, please bring your state ID with you to enter the school building.

post_text: Hickory Creek Principal Will Seidelmann, Director of Special Services Jen Bajda, Seventh-Grade Teacher Susan Niendorf, and Director of Curriculum and Instruction Janet McClarence, along with Superintendent Dr. Maura Zinni (behind the camera), are attending the U.S. Department of Education's awards ceremony for 2018 National Blue Ribbon Schools in Washington, D.C.! Niendorf's colleagues voted for her to attend the ceremony.

post_text:
Parents in the Lincoln-Way area are invited to attend a free presentation by New York Times bestselling author Julie Lythcott-Haims on October 18 at Lincoln-Way East High School.

The speaking event is set to take place from 6:00 to 7:30 p.m. in the school's auditorium and is being hosted jointly by Frankfort School District 157-C and Lincoln-Way High School District 210.

Lythcott-Haims is the author of "How to Raise an Adult: Break Free of the Overparenting Trap and Prepare Your Kid for Success."

Click on the article below to learn more.

post_text: "Taking a team of district staff to this training was educational and eye-opening," Dr. Zinni said. "This national epidemic has impacted our community, and as education professionals, we need to recognize the statistics and be prepared in the event we were presented with a situation where one of our students or adults visiting our campuses was in need of this life-saving treatment. Though we hope to never have to use our training, we are now prepared with the tools and skills to save a life."
shared_text:
CHICAGOTRIBUNE.COM
Frankfort 157-C staff members become trained in administration of lifesaving overdose reversal medication naloxone
text:

Though we hope to never have to use our training, we are now prepared with the tools and skills to save a life."

post_text:
Grand Prairie Elementary School invites the public to attend a ribbon cutting at 6:30 p.m. Wednesday, August 15, at the school's recently renovated library, 10480 W. Nebraska St. in Frankfort.

The library was renovated over the summer, and the work was made possible by a grant from the FSD 157-C Education Foundation.
